p.text: Subject to this Part, the Court of Appeal shall consist of—
the Chief Justice who shall, by virtue of his or her office, be a Judge of Appeal and the senior member of the Court of Appeal;
the President of the Court of Appeal; and
such other Judges as are appointed to be Judges of Appeal.
[s 42 am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 91 of 1999 s 4 and Sch 2]
Any 3 or more Judges of Appeal constitute the Court of Appeal.
[subs (1) am Act 14 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 1]
At a sitting of the Court of Appeal at which the Chief Justice is present the Chief Justice shall preside.
[subs (2) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
In the absence of the Chief Justice, the President of the Court of Appeal shall preside.
In the absence of both the Chief Justice and the President, the senior Judge of Appeal present shall preside.
[subs (5) rep Act 88 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 1]
[subs (6) rep Act 14 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 1]

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 43.5] Constitution of the Court of Appeal by 2 judges

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 43.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 46, s 46A, s 46B, s 46B(2), s 46B(3).

heading.title: Constitution of the Court of Appeal by 2 judges

p.text: Under s 46A , two judges of appeal may constitute the court to hear damages appeals in proceedings relating to death or bodily injury. SCA s 46B provides that certain other matters (including applications for leave to appeal and interlocutory applications) can be heard and determined by two judges of appeal if the formalities of directions of the Chief Justice under SCA s 46B(2) and the President of the Court of Appeal under SCA s 46B(3) are observed. Lack of notice of such directions to a party does not invalidate the subsequent hearing. Where two judges act in open court to hear and determine an application for leave to appeal, there is a presumption of regularity: Rahman v Riordan [2010] NSWCA 288; BC201008364 ; Rahman v Dubs [2012] NSWCA 98; BC201202353 at [15] (orders challenged, among other issues, on the basis that the application for leave to appeal was heard by two judges of appeal only — notice of motion dismissed).

A single judge of appeal may also exercise the powers conferred by s 46 . Apart from those sections, the Court of Appeal must be constituted by three judges of appeal. It is no longer possible for multiple divisional judges to sit together to determine a test case, as had been the practice under s 6 of the Equity Act 1901: see, for example, Re Louis [1971] 1 NSWLR 164.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 43.10] Reconstitution where hearing is part heard

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 43.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 43(1).

heading.title: Reconstitution where hearing is part heard

p.text: Ordinarily, once the hearing of a matter has commenced, the court as then constituted should hear and determine all aspects of the matter: R v Marrington (1850) 1 SCR (NSW) App 11 (Appendix 11); Ex parte Ryan (1864) 3 SCR (NSW) 221; Fulker v Fulker [1936] 3 All ER 636; Whittle v Whittle [1939] 1 All ER 374; Munday v Munday [1954] 2 All ER 667; [1954] 1 WLR 1078; Coleshill v Manchester Corp [1928] 1 KB 776; see generally [SCA s 40.10] .

However, this principle is obviously of greater importance in first instance proceedings, where the court must hear and see the various witnesses, than in the case of appeals: Bakarich v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (No 2) [2012] NSWCA 390; BC201210612 at [50] . In an appropriate case (for example, the death or absence of a judge) the Court of Appeal does have power to reconstitute in order to comply with the statutory requirement in s 43(1) that three or more judges shall constitute the Court of Appeal: Cotogno v Lamb (1985) 3 NSWLR 221 at 223; Monaghan Surveyors Pty Ltd v Stratford Glen-Avon Pty Ltd [2012] NSWCA 347; BC201208239 (Basten JA, McColl JA and Young AJA agreeing) (judge retired between judgment and final orders — court reconstituted with retired judge sitting in a different capacity).

The power has been applied to permit the reconstitution of the court for the substantive hearing after the determination of a preliminary matter: Cotogno v Lamb, above; to the reconstitution for the purpose of making final orders after the determination of remitted proceedings: Bakarich v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (No 2) [2012] NSWCA 390; BC201210612 at [60] ; and to reconstitution for the purpose of dealing with an application vary a punishment for contempt: C v Registrar, Court of Appeal [1995] NSWCA 67; BC9508215 .
Legislation cited in [SCA s 43.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 45A.

As s 45A expressly provides, it is not necessary for a reserved decision of the Court of Appeal to be announced by a court constituted by the same judges as those who heard the appeal. It is common for the court to be constituted differently and to deal with procedural matters, such as making formal orders in accordance with the published reasons for judgment. If there is controversy about the substance of the orders to be made, it will be necessary to reconstitute the court that heard the appeal.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 43.20] Audio visual and telephone proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 43.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Part 36 r 2A, Pt 77 Div 51.
(NSW) Evidence (Audio and Audio Visual Links) Act 1998.

Part 36 r 2A permits the court to direct proceedings to be conducted by audio visual means or by telephone. Under different legislation, it has been held that if submissions are being made by telephone, the judges may be regarded as “sitting together” in “open court” even though they are not physically present in the one room: Director-General, Dept of Community Services v De Lewinski (1996) FLC ¶92-674. See also the Evidence (Audio and Audio Visual Links) Act 1998 behind the “Evidence Act” guide card and Pt 77 Div 51 of the Supreme Court Rules 1970.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 43.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 85.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Pt 31 r 2.

As an incident of the Court of Appeal's power to control its own procedure, an appeal may be heard in several stages or the court may determine separate questions akin to a judge at first instance (see s 85 , Pt 31 r 2 ): see Multicon Engineering Pty Ltd v Federal Airports Corp (NSWCA, Powell JA, No 40220/96, 3 June 1997, unreported, BC9702207).
More than one sitting of the Court of Appeal (constituted by 2 or more Judges of Appeal) may be held at the same time.
[s 43A insrt Act 88 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 1]
The Court of Appeal may, in proceedings before it, exercise every power, jurisdiction or authority of the Court, whether at law or in equity or under any Act, Imperial Act or Commonwealth Act.
The decision of the Court of Appeal shall be in accordance with the opinion of the majority of the Judges of Appeal present.
[subs (1) am Act 226 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 1]
If the Judges of Appeal present are equally divided in opinion the decision of the Court of Appeal shall be in accordance with the opinion of the Chief Justice or other the Judge of Appeal presiding.
[subs (3) rep Act 39 of 1999 s 3 and Sch 7]

If, in dismissing an appeal, the Court of Appeal is of the unanimous opinion that the appeal does not raise any question of general principle, it may, in accordance with the rules, give reasons for its decision in short form.
[subs (4) insrt Act 111 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]
Legislation cited in [SCA s 45.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 SCA s 45(2).

It sometimes occurs that the reasons for judgment are so diverse that it is difficult to obtain a majority in favour of any particular orders to dispose of the proceedings. In these cases it will also be difficult to characterise the court as “equally divided in opinion” so as to attract SCA s 45(2) . A number of different proposals have been considered as to the appropriate way of resolving difficulties of these kinds: see Skulander v Willoughby City Council [2007] NSWCA 116; BC200703790 at [42]–[74] . One possibility, and it is described as a convention, is that in cases of disagreement of this kind the judgment of the junior judge is withdrawn and the disposal of the proceedings is determined by the application of s 45(2) : in O’Brien v Tanning Research Laboratories Inc (1988) 14 NSWLR 601 at 641; 84 ALR 221 ; Woolworths Ltd v Kelly (No 2) (NSWCA, Kirby P, Samuels and Mahoney JJA, No 40357/91, 29 August 1991, unreported, BC9101610) (orders made by majority); Government Insurance Office (NSW) v Rosniak (NSWCA, 5 September 1991, unreported) (acquiescence in orders proposed by a senior judge). Alternatively, a judge whose judgment turns on one particular point, may deliver reasons for judgment that specifically deal with another point on which the other judges have differed: Tasmania v Victoria (1935) 52 CLR 157 at 183–4; [1935] ALR 157 ; Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd v Tindal (1940) 63 CLR 232; [1940] ALR 197 ; Pennant Hills Restaurants Pty Ltd v Barrell Insurances Pty Ltd [1977] 2 NSWLR 827 at 866; Ross v Esanda Ltd [1977] ACLD 879 and Metropolitan Water Sewerage and Drainage Board v Histon [1982] 2 NSWLR 720; Skulander v Willoughby City Council [2007] NSWCA 116; BC200703790 at [42]–[74] (judge agreeing in contributory negligence despite dissent on liability).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 45.10] Short form reasons for decision

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 45.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 51.55.
UCPR r 51.55 permits the Court of Appeal to give short form reasons for dismissing an appeal.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 45AA] s 45AA Continuation of appeal if one or more Judges unable to continue

leg:heading.title: Continuation of appeal if one or more Judges unable to continue

p.text: If an appeal is commenced before 3 or more Judges of Appeal and, before the appeal is determined, one or more of the Judges dies, resigns from office or otherwise becomes unable to continue as a member of the Court of Appeal for the purposes of the appeal, the hearing and determination of the appeal may be completed by the remaining Judges of Appeal so long as at least 2 Judges remain and the parties consent.
If the appeal concerned is to be heard and determined by only 2 Judges of Appeal and those Judges are divided in opinion:

as to the decision determining the appeal — the appeal is to be reheard and determined by the Court of Appeal constituted by such 3 or more Judges of Appeal as the President of the Court of Appeal directs (including, if practicable, the 2 Judges of Appeal who completed the hearing of the appeal), or
as to any other decision — the decision of the Court is to be in accordance with the opinion of the senior Judge present.
This section has effect despite any other provision of this Division.
[s 45AA insrt Act 39 of 1999 s 3 and Sch 7]

Subject to statutory provisions, it is permissible for another judge to complete a part-heard case, rather than starting the hearing afresh: see [SCA s 40.10] and [SCA s 43.10] . The principal factors that influence the propriety of reconstituting the court appear to be the likelihood of a significant evidentiary conflict, and the attitude of the parties: Brennan v Brennan (1953) 89 CLR 129 at 136–137; [1953] ALR 528; (1953) 27 ALJR 120; BC5300600 ; Bakarich v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (No 2) [2012] NSWCA 390; BC201210612 at [36] . Under the general law the consent of the parties to another judge continuing with the case has been regarded as an important consideration in some cases: Brennan v Brennan (1953) 89 CLR 129; [1953] ALR 528; (1953) 27 ALJR 120; BC5300600 . But the consent of the parties cannot be determinative if it is inherently impossible for a reconstituted court to determine the contested issues fairly and properly: Bakarich v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (No 2) at [38]–[49].

The present rule specifically authorises the Court of Appeal to be effectively constituted by 2 judges where another judge is unable to continue. But the rule is subject to the consent of the parties, and is not the only basis on which the Court of Appeal may be reconstituted for the purpose of disposing of proceedings: Bakarich v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (No 2) at [33], [49] & [60]; (two members of the court unavailable); see further [SCA s 43.10] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 45A] s 45A Judgment of Court of Appeal may be delivered by single Judge of Appeal

leg:heading.title: Judgment of Court of Appeal may be delivered by single Judge of Appeal*

p.text: When judgment in a proceeding in the Court of Appeal is delivered it is not necessary for any of the Judges of Appeal before whom it was heard to be present in court to state their opinions.
The opinion of any of the Judges of Appeal may be reduced to writing and made public by any Judge of Appeal when judgment in the proceeding is delivered.
The judgment of the Court of Appeal has the same effect as if each Judge of Appeal whose opinion is so made public had been present in court and declared his or her opinion in person.
For the purpose of delivering judgment the Court of Appeal may be constituted by one or more Judges of Appeal.
[s 45A insrt Act 14 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 46] s 46 Powers of Judge of Appeal

p.text: A Judge of Appeal may exercise the powers of the Court of Appeal—
to give any judgment by consent or make any order by consent;
to dismiss an appeal or other proceedings for want of prosecution or for other cause specified in the rules;
to dismiss an appeal or other proceedings on the application of the appellant or plaintiff; or
to deal with costs and other matters incidental to the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) , (b) and (c) .
[subs (1) am Act 226 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 1]
A Judge of Appeal may exercise the powers of the Court of Appeal—
to make any order or give any direction concerning the institution of an appeal or other proceedings in the Court of Appeal; or
to make any order or give any direction in any appeal or other proceedings, but not an order or direction involving the determination or decision of the appeal or other proceedings.
Subsection (2) does not authorise a Judge of Appeal to grant or refuse leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal.
The Court of Appeal may discharge or vary a judgment given by a Judge of Appeal, or an order made or direction given by a Judge of Appeal.

ci:cite.ci:content: 15 and 16 Geo 5 c 49 s 69(2); Act 21 of 1899 s 254A(3); Act 35 of 1900 s 20(3); Court of Appeal Rules r 23

p.text: [subs (4) am Act 226 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 1]

Subject to subsection (4) , a judgment, order or direction given or made by a Judge of Appeal is to have effect as a judgment, order or direction of the Court of Appeal, whether or not the judgment, order or direction is within the powers of the Judge of Appeal under this section.
[subs (5) subst Act 226 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 1]
[s 46 subst Act 41 of 1972 s 4]
Transitional provisions in relation to the operation of s 45A were inserted in the Fourth Schedule of the Supreme Court Act 1970.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 46.5] Power to make any order by consent or any other order not involving determination of an appeal

heading.title: Power to make any order by consent or any other order not involving determination of an appeal

p.text: This section is an important means of contributing to the flexibility and efficiency of the work of the court and should be given a broad construction to enable it to contribute to that end: Wentworth v Wentworth (1994) 35 NSWLR 726 per Mahoney JA.
Examples of situations where a single judge of appeal may exercise the powers of the court include the following:

on applications for a stay pending appeal (Grose v State Bank of New South Wales (NSWCA, Full Court, 15 October 1991, unreported, BC9101496)) and in giving directions about the preparation of appeals before the court.

dismissing an appeal as incompetent: Macatangay v NSW (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 272; BC200908153 at [15] . Strike out a claim or document (as frivolous, scandalous or without merit): Hannover Life Re of Australasia Ltd v Dargan [2012] NSWCA 185; BC201204367 at [12], [13] (notice of contention)

making appropriate restitution orders after the determination of an appeal. Such orders may include an order for the repayment, with interest, of part of a judgment debt paid by a successful appellant pending the appeal: Government Insurance Office (NSW) v Healy (No 2) (1991) 22 NSWLR 380; BC9102212 . As to the court's general powers in relation to restitution, see [SCA s 75A.20] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 46.10] Discharge or variation of a single judge's orders

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 46.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 121(3), s 19(2), s 46(4).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 49.19, rr 51.2, 51.58.

heading.title: Discharge or variation of a single judge's orders

p.text: Proceedings under s 46(4) are not appeals: see SCA s 19(2) and UCPR rr 51.2 and 51.58 . Nevertheless, the subsection does not confer an unrestricted right to a new hearing of the matters in contest. Rather, the applicant for review must show that there has been an error of principle in the exercise of the power or that the decision was plainly wrong: Transglobal Capital Pty Ltd v Yolarno Pty Ltd (2004) 60 NSWLR 143; [2004] NSWCA 136; BC200402460 (at [4], [6]); Te Kanawa v Leading Edge Events Australia Pty Ltd [2007] NSWCA 274; BC200708547 at [14] ; Lo v Iverach [2009] NSWCA 92; BC200903365 at [29] ; Patrick v Howorth [2002] NSWCA 285; BC200205001 ; Morrison v State Transit Authority of New South Wales (NSWCA, 3 December 1990, unreported) (applicant must show that the single judge's exercise of discretion miscarried); Knaggs v Solicitors' Statutory Committee (NSWCA, No 04060/90, 8 October 1990, unreported, BC9001908) (applicant must show that the discretion miscarried); Kiri Te Kanawa v Leading Edge Events Australia Pty Ltd (2004) 60 NSWLR 143 (at [4], [6]); [2007] NSWCA 274; BC200708547 at [14] (grounds not made out); Lo v Iverach [2009] NSWCA 92; BC200903365 at [29] (no discharge or variation of judge’s orders); Rinehart v Welker [2011] NSWCA 403; BC201110513 (suppression order — failure to consider relevant principle). This construction of the power is essentially the same as the accepted principle governing the review of dicretionary decisions: see House v R (1936) 55 CLR 499; 10 ALJR 202 and derives either from the legislative context: Wentworth v Wentworth (1994) 35 NSWLR 726 per Mahoney and Powell JJA, or from the basic proposition that an application to discharge or vary is essentially a matter of practice and procedure in relation to which the restrictive principles set out in In the Will of Gilbert (1946) 46 SR (NSW) 318; 63 WN (NSW) 176 will apply: Wentworth v Wentworth , above. It should be noted that the approach taken in these cases implies that the SCA s 46(4) power is more restricted than the analogous powers to review the determinations of masters, registrars and other officers of the court — as to which see SCA s 121(3) , UCPR r 49.19 and note [49.19.5] , and Patrick v Howorth , above, at [5].

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 46.15] Review of decisions made by a registrar

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 46.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 121(3), s 46(4).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 49.19, r 51.59.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 SCR Pt 61 r 4.

heading.title: Review of decisions made by a registrar

p.text: The power to review a decision of a registrar is properly found in SCA s 121(3) and UCPR r 49.19 . The fact that a registrar may have exercised the powers of a judge of appeal does not attract the variation power conferred by SCA s 46(4) in relation to a judgment or order made by a Judge of Appeal: Tomko v Palasty (No 2) [2007] NSWCA 369; BC200710980 at [4], [40] per Hodgson and Basten JJA, at [17] per Ipp J agreeing. (This view differs from those previously expressed, or assumed, in Strata Consolidated (Australia) Pty Ltd v Bradshaw [2000] NSWCA 225; BC200004852 ; Emmett v Hornsby Shire Council [2002] NSWCA 75; BC200201083 (Sheller JA) and Wentworth v Graham (2002) 55 NSWLR 638; [2002] NSWCA 397; BC200207449 — a decision involving the former SCR Pt 61 r 4 ). UCPR r 51.59 permits a single Judge of Appeal to review a decision given by the registrar. (The rule resolves the doubts expressed in Penrith Whitewater Stadium Ltd v Lesvos Enterprises Pty Ltd [2007] NSWCA 131; BC200704476 at [5]–[10] per Basten JA (proposed orders to be made formally at the hearing of the appeal); Preston v Harbour Pacific Underwriting Management Pty Ltd [2007] NSWCA 247; BC200711769 at [6] per Basten JA, Hoeben JA agreeing at [40].)
Note: The review is not an appeal. The scope of the review procedure is discussed in [49.19.5] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 46A] s 46A Certain appeals may be heard by 2 Judges of Appeal

leg:heading.title: Certain appeals may be heard by 2 Judges of Appeal*

p.text: This section applies to an appeal to the Court of Appeal:
from any court, where the appeal relates solely to the amount of damages awarded in respect of the death of, or bodily injury to, a person, or

from the Compensation Court or the District Court (in respect of a matter that would have been within the jurisdiction of the Compensation Court had the Compensation Court Repeal Act 2002 not been enacted), where the appeal relates solely to the amount of compensation awarded by that Court, or
from the Dust Diseases Tribunal, where the appeal relates solely to the amount of compensation awarded by that Tribunal, or
from a court or tribunal (other than the Supreme Court), where:
the leave of the Court of Appeal is required in respect of the appeal, and
the appeal is not against a final judgment, order, award or decision of the court or tribunal (other than an order for the payment of costs).
[subs (1) subst Act 141 of 1997 s 3 and Sch 1 ; am Act 49 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 23 ; Act 31 of 2000 Sch 13 ; Act 23 of 2002 s 12 and Sch 1, effective 1 January 2004]
The Chief Justice may direct that such an appeal be heard and determined by such 2 Judges of Appeal as the President of the Court of Appeal directs.
Such a direction may only be given if the Chief Justice is of the opinion that the appeal is not likely to require the resolution of a disputed issue of general principle.
For the purpose of an appeal the subject of a direction under this section, the Court of Appeal is constituted by the 2 Judges directed by the President of the Court of Appeal.
The decision of the Court of Appeal when constituted by 2 Judges is to be in accordance with the opinion of those Judges.
If the Judges are divided in opinion:

as to the decision determining the proceedings, the appeal is to be reheard and determined by the Court of Appeal constituted by such 3 Judges of Appeal as the President of the Court of Appeal directs (including, if practicable, the 2 Judges who first heard the appeal); or
as to any other decision, the decision of the Court is to be in accordance with the opinion of the senior Judge present.

Proceedings heard by the Court of Appeal constituted by 2 Judges under this section are rendered abortive for the purposes of section 6A(1)(a1) of the Suitors' Fund Act 1951 if they are required to be reheard because the judges were divided in opinion as to the decision determining the proceedings. The rehearing of the proceedings is considered to be a new trial for the purposes of that Act.
[s 46A insrt Act 14 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 1 ; am Act 49 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 23]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 46B] s 46B Certain other matters may be heard by 2 Judges

leg:heading.title: Certain other matters may be heard by 2 Judges

p.text: This section applies to the following applications:
applications for leave to appeal,

applications involving a question of practice and procedure in an appeal or other matter in the Court of Appeal (being applications that are not capable of being dealt with by a single Judge of Appeal).
The Chief Justice may direct that such an application be heard and determined by such 2 Judges of Appeal as the President of the Court of Appeal directs.

For the purpose of hearing and determining an application the subject of a direction under this section, the Court of Appeal is constituted by the 2 Judges directed by the President of the Court of Appeal.
The decision of the Court of Appeal when constituted by 2 Judges of Appeal is to be in accordance with the opinion of those Judges.
If the judges are divided in opinion, the application is to be reheard and determined by the Court of Appeal constituted by 3 Judges of Appeal.
[s 46B insrt Act 88 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 1]
Transitional provisions in relation to the operation of s 46A were inserted in the Fourth Schedule of the Supreme Court Act 1970.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 46B.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 ss 46, s 46(1)(b), 46A, 46B.

The Court of Appeal constituted by two judges of appeal pursuant to SCA s 46(1)(b) may exercise the powers of a single judge. The words in parenthesis “being application that are not capable of being dealt with by a single Judge of Appeal”, are words of expansion, not exclusion: Martin v NSW (No 15) [2012] NSWCA 47; BC201201593 at [13] (alleged procedural irregularity by reference to SCA ss 46 , 46A and 46B — motion dismissed).
